trans-unit.source: Azure Queues and Service Bus queues - compared and contrasted
trans-unit.target: Azure Queues and Service Bus queues - compared and contrasted

trans-unit.source: Analyzes differences and similarities between two types of queues offered by Azure.
trans-unit.target: Analyzes differences and similarities between two types of queues offered by Azure.

trans-unit.source: Azure Queues and Service Bus queues - compared and contrasted
trans-unit.target: Azure Queues and Service Bus queues - compared and contrasted

trans-unit.source: This article analyzes the differences and similarities between the two types of queues offered by Microsoft Azure today: Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: This article analyzes the differences and similarities between the two types of queues offered by Microsoft Azure today: Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: By using this information, you can compare and contrast the respective technologies and be able to make a more informed decision about which solution best meets your needs.
trans-unit.target: By using this information, you can compare and contrast the respective technologies and be able to make a more informed decision about which solution best meets your needs.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure supports two types of queue mechanisms: **Azure Queues** and **Service Bus Queues**.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure supports two types of queue mechanisms: **Azure Queues** and **Service Bus Queues**.

trans-unit.source: **Azure Queues**, which are part of the [Azure storage](http://azure.microsoft.com/services/storage/) infrastructure, feature a simple REST-based Get/Put/Peek interface, providing reliable, persistent messaging within and between services.
trans-unit.target: **Azure Queues**, which are part of the [Azure storage](http://azure.microsoft.com/services/storage/) infrastructure, feature a simple REST-based Get/Put/Peek interface, providing reliable, persistent messaging within and between services.

trans-unit.source: **Service Bus queues** are part of a broader [Azure messaging](http://azure.microsoft.com/services/messaging/) infrastructure that supports queuing as well as publish/subscribe, Web service remoting, and integration patterns.
trans-unit.target: **Service Bus queues** are part of a broader [Azure messaging](http://azure.microsoft.com/services/messaging/) infrastructure that supports queuing as well as publish/subscribe, Web service remoting, and integration patterns.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Service Bus queues, topics/subscriptions, and relays, see [Overview of Service Bus Messaging Patterns](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh410103.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Service Bus queues, topics/subscriptions, and relays, see [Overview of Service Bus Messaging Patterns](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh410103.aspx).

trans-unit.source: While both queuing technologies exist concurrently, Azure Queues were introduced first, as a dedicated queue storage mechanism built on top of the Azure storage services.
trans-unit.target: While both queuing technologies exist concurrently, Azure Queues were introduced first, as a dedicated queue storage mechanism built on top of the Azure storage services.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues are built on top of the broader "brokered messaging" infrastructure designed to integrate applications or application components that may span multiple communication protocols, data contracts, trust domains, and/or network environments.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues are built on top of the broader "brokered messaging" infrastructure designed to integrate applications or application components that may span multiple communication protocols, data contracts, trust domains, and/or network environments.

trans-unit.source: This article compares the two queue technologies offered by Azure by discussing the differences in the behavior and implementation of the features provided by each.
trans-unit.target: This article compares the two queue technologies offered by Azure by discussing the differences in the behavior and implementation of the features provided by each.

trans-unit.source: The article also provides guidance for choosing which features might best suit your application development needs.
trans-unit.target: The article also provides guidance for choosing which features might best suit your application development needs.

trans-unit.source: Both Azure Queues and Service Bus queues are implementations of the message queuing service currently offered on Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: Both Azure Queues and Service Bus queues are implementations of the message queuing service currently offered on Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: Each has a slightly different feature set, which means you can choose one or the other, or use both, depending on the needs of your particular solution or business/technical problem you are solving.
trans-unit.target: Each has a slightly different feature set, which means you can choose one or the other, or use both, depending on the needs of your particular solution or business/technical problem you are solving.

trans-unit.source: When determining which queuing technology fits the purpose for a given solution, solution architects and developers should consider the recommendations below.
trans-unit.target: When determining which queuing technology fits the purpose for a given solution, solution architects and developers should consider the recommendations below.

trans-unit.source: For more details, see the next section.
trans-unit.target: For more details, see the next section.

trans-unit.source: As a solution architect/developer, **you should consider using Azure Queues** when:
trans-unit.target: As a solution architect/developer, **you should consider using Azure Queues** when:

trans-unit.source: Your application must store over 80 GB of messages in a queue, where the messages have a lifetime shorter than 7 days.
trans-unit.target: Your application must store over 80 GB of messages in a queue, where the messages have a lifetime shorter than 7 days.

trans-unit.source: Your application wants to track progress for processing a message inside of the queue.
trans-unit.target: Your application wants to track progress for processing a message inside of the queue.

trans-unit.source: This is useful if the worker processing a message crashes.
trans-unit.target: This is useful if the worker processing a message crashes.

trans-unit.source: A subsequent worker can then use that information to continue from where the prior worker left off.
trans-unit.target: A subsequent worker can then use that information to continue from where the prior worker left off.

trans-unit.source: You require server side logs of all of the transactions executed against your queues.
trans-unit.target: You require server side logs of all of the transactions executed against your queues.

trans-unit.source: As a solution architect/developer, **you should consider using Service Bus queues** when:
trans-unit.target: As a solution architect/developer, **you should consider using Service Bus queues** when:

trans-unit.source: Your solution must be able to receive messages without having to poll the queue.
trans-unit.target: Your solution must be able to receive messages without having to poll the queue.

trans-unit.source: With Service Bus, this can be achieved through the use of the long-polling receive operation using the TCP-based protocols that Service Bus supports.
trans-unit.target: With Service Bus, this can be achieved through the use of the long-polling receive operation using the TCP-based protocols that Service Bus supports.

trans-unit.source: Your solution requires the queue to provide a guaranteed first-in-first-out (FIFO) ordered delivery.
trans-unit.target: Your solution requires the queue to provide a guaranteed first-in-first-out (FIFO) ordered delivery.

trans-unit.source: You want a symmetric experience in Azure and on Windows Server (private cloud).
trans-unit.target: You want a symmetric experience in Azure and on Windows Server (private cloud).

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Service Bus for Windows Server](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn282144.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Service Bus for Windows Server](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn282144.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Your solution must be able to support automatic duplicate detection.
trans-unit.target: Your solution must be able to support automatic duplicate detection.

trans-unit.source: You want your application to process messages as parallel long-running streams (messages are associated with a stream using the [SessionId](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.sessionid.aspx) property on the message).
trans-unit.target: You want your application to process messages as parallel long-running streams (messages are associated with a stream using the [SessionId](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.sessionid.aspx) property on the message).

trans-unit.source: In this model, each node in the consuming application competes for streams, as opposed to messages.
trans-unit.target: In this model, each node in the consuming application competes for streams, as opposed to messages.

trans-unit.source: When a stream is given to a consuming node, the node can examine the state of the application stream state using transactions.
trans-unit.target: When a stream is given to a consuming node, the node can examine the state of the application stream state using transactions.

trans-unit.source: Your solution requires transactional behavior and atomicity when sending or receiving multiple messages from a queue.
trans-unit.target: Your solution requires transactional behavior and atomicity when sending or receiving multiple messages from a queue.

trans-unit.source: The time-to-live (TTL) characteristic of the application-specific workload can exceed the 7-day period.
trans-unit.target: The time-to-live (TTL) characteristic of the application-specific workload can exceed the 7-day period.

trans-unit.source: Your application handles messages that can exceed 64 KB but will not likely approach the 256 KB limit.
trans-unit.target: Your application handles messages that can exceed 64 KB but will not likely approach the 256 KB limit.

trans-unit.source: You deal with a requirement to provide a role-based access model to the queues, and different rights/permissions for senders and receivers.
trans-unit.target: You deal with a requirement to provide a role-based access model to the queues, and different rights/permissions for senders and receivers.

trans-unit.source: Your queue size will not grow larger than 80 GB.
trans-unit.target: Your queue size will not grow larger than 80 GB.

trans-unit.source: You want to use the AMQP 1.0 standards-based messaging broker.
trans-unit.target: You want to use the AMQP 1.0 standards-based messaging broker.

trans-unit.source: For more information about AMQP, see [Service Bus AMQP Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/jj841072.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about AMQP, see [Service Bus AMQP Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/jj841072.aspx).

trans-unit.source: You can envision an eventual migration from queue-based point-to-point communication to a message exchange pattern that enables seamless integration of additional receivers (subscribers), each of which receives independent copies of either some or all messages sent to the queue.
trans-unit.target: You can envision an eventual migration from queue-based point-to-point communication to a message exchange pattern that enables seamless integration of additional receivers (subscribers), each of which receives independent copies of either some or all messages sent to the queue.

trans-unit.source: The latter refers to the publish/subscribe capability natively provided by Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: The latter refers to the publish/subscribe capability natively provided by Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: Your messaging solution must be able to support the “At-Most-Once” delivery guarantee without the need for you to build the additional infrastructure components.
trans-unit.target: Your messaging solution must be able to support the “At-Most-Once” delivery guarantee without the need for you to build the additional infrastructure components.

trans-unit.source: You would like to be able to publish and consume batches of messages.
trans-unit.target: You would like to be able to publish and consume batches of messages.

trans-unit.source: You require full integration with the Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) communication stack in the .NET Framework.
trans-unit.target: You require full integration with the Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) communication stack in the .NET Framework.

trans-unit.source: Comparing Azure Queues and Service Bus Queues
trans-unit.target: Comparing Azure Queues and Service Bus Queues

trans-unit.source: The tables in the following sections provide a logical grouping of queue features and let you compare, at a glance, the capabilities available in both Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: The tables in the following sections provide a logical grouping of queue features and let you compare, at a glance, the capabilities available in both Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: This section compares some of the fundamental queuing capabilities provided by Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: This section compares some of the fundamental queuing capabilities provided by Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the first note in the “Additional Information” section.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the first note in the “Additional Information” section.

trans-unit.source: (completes immediately if no new message is found)
trans-unit.target: (completes immediately if no new message is found)

trans-unit.source: (through the use of .NET managed API only)
trans-unit.target: (through the use of .NET managed API only)

trans-unit.source: **7 days (maximum)** (You can renew or release a message lease using the [UpdateMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.windowsazure.storage.queue.cloudqueue.updatemessage.aspx) API.)
trans-unit.target: **7 days (maximum)** (You can renew or release a message lease using the [UpdateMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.windowsazure.storage.queue.cloudqueue.updatemessage.aspx) API.)

trans-unit.source: You can renew a message lock using the [RenewLock](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.renewlock.aspx) API.
trans-unit.target: You can renew a message lock using the [RenewLock](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.renewlock.aspx) API.

trans-unit.source: (each message can have a different timeout value, which you can then update as needed while processing the message, by using the [UpdateMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.windowsazure.storage.queue.cloudqueue.updatemessage.aspx) API)
trans-unit.target: (each message can have a different timeout value, which you can then update as needed while processing the message, by using the [UpdateMessage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.windowsazure.storage.queue.cloudqueue.updatemessage.aspx) API)

trans-unit.source: (each queue has a lock precision applied to all of its messages, but you can renew the lock using the [RenewLock](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.renewlock.aspx) API.)
trans-unit.target: (each queue has a lock precision applied to all of its messages, but you can renew the lock using the [RenewLock](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.renewlock.aspx) API.)

trans-unit.source: (explicitly specifying message count when retrieving messages, up to a maximum of 32 messages)
trans-unit.target: (explicitly specifying message count when retrieving messages, up to a maximum of 32 messages)

trans-unit.source: (implicitly enabling a pre-fetch property or explicitly through the use of transactions)
trans-unit.target: (implicitly enabling a pre-fetch property or explicitly through the use of transactions)

trans-unit.source: (through the use of transactions or client-side batching)
trans-unit.target: (through the use of transactions or client-side batching)

trans-unit.source: Messages in Azure Queues are typically first-in-first-out, but sometimes they can be out of order; for example, when a message’s visibility timeout duration expires (for example, as a result of a client application crashing during processing).
trans-unit.target: Messages in Azure Queues are typically first-in-first-out, but sometimes they can be out of order; for example, when a message’s visibility timeout duration expires (for example, as a result of a client application crashing during processing).

trans-unit.source: When the visibility timeout expires, the message becomes visible again on the queue for another worker to dequeue it.
trans-unit.target: When the visibility timeout expires, the message becomes visible again on the queue for another worker to dequeue it.

trans-unit.source: At that point, the newly visible message might be placed in the queue (to be dequeued again) after a message that was originally enqueued after it.
trans-unit.target: At that point, the newly visible message might be placed in the queue (to be dequeued again) after a message that was originally enqueued after it.

trans-unit.source: If you are already using Azure Storage Blobs or Tables and you start using queues, you are guaranteed 99.9% availability.
trans-unit.target: If you are already using Azure Storage Blobs or Tables and you start using queues, you are guaranteed 99.9% availability.

trans-unit.source: If you use Blobs or Tables with Service Bus queues, you will have lower availability.
trans-unit.target: If you use Blobs or Tables with Service Bus queues, you will have lower availability.

trans-unit.source: The guaranteed FIFO pattern in Service Bus queues requires the use of messaging sessions.
trans-unit.target: The guaranteed FIFO pattern in Service Bus queues requires the use of messaging sessions.

trans-unit.source: In the event that the application crashes while processing a message received in the **Peek & Lock** mode, the next time a queue receiver accepts a messaging session, it will start with the failed message after its time-to-live (TTL) period expires.
trans-unit.target: In the event that the application crashes while processing a message received in the **Peek & Lock** mode, the next time a queue receiver accepts a messaging session, it will start with the failed message after its time-to-live (TTL) period expires.

trans-unit.source: Azure Queues are designed to support standard queuing scenarios, such as decoupling application components to increase scalability and tolerance for failures, load leveling, and building process workflows.
trans-unit.target: Azure Queues are designed to support standard queuing scenarios, such as decoupling application components to increase scalability and tolerance for failures, load leveling, and building process workflows.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues support the *At-Least-Once* delivery guarantee.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues support the *At-Least-Once* delivery guarantee.

trans-unit.source: In addition, the *At-Most-Once* semantic can be supported by using session state to store the application state and by using transactions to atomically receive messages and update the session state.
trans-unit.target: In addition, the *At-Most-Once* semantic can be supported by using session state to store the application state and by using transactions to atomically receive messages and update the session state.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Workflow Service uses this technique to guarantee At-Most-Once delivery.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Workflow Service uses this technique to guarantee At-Most-Once delivery.

trans-unit.source: Azure Queues provide a uniform and consistent programming model across queues, tables, and BLOBs – both for developers and for operations teams.
trans-unit.target: Azure Queues provide a uniform and consistent programming model across queues, tables, and BLOBs – both for developers and for operations teams.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues provide support for local transactions in the context of a single queue.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues provide support for local transactions in the context of a single queue.

trans-unit.source: The *Receive and Delete* mode supported by Service Bus provides the ability to reduce the messaging operation count (and associated cost) in exchange for lowered delivery assurance.
trans-unit.target: The *Receive and Delete* mode supported by Service Bus provides the ability to reduce the messaging operation count (and associated cost) in exchange for lowered delivery assurance.

trans-unit.source: Azure Queues provide leases with the ability to extend the leases for messages.
trans-unit.target: Azure Queues provide leases with the ability to extend the leases for messages.

trans-unit.source: This allows the workers to maintain short leases on messages.
trans-unit.target: This allows the workers to maintain short leases on messages.

trans-unit.source: Thus, if a worker crashes, the message can be quickly processed again by another worker.
trans-unit.target: Thus, if a worker crashes, the message can be quickly processed again by another worker.

trans-unit.source: In addition, a worker can extend the lease on a message if it needs to process it longer than the current lease time.
trans-unit.target: In addition, a worker can extend the lease on a message if it needs to process it longer than the current lease time.

trans-unit.source: Azure Queues offer a visibility timeout that you can set upon the enqueueing or dequeuing of a message.
trans-unit.target: Azure Queues offer a visibility timeout that you can set upon the enqueueing or dequeuing of a message.

trans-unit.source: In addition, you can update a message with different lease values at runtime, and update different values across messages in the same queue.
trans-unit.target: In addition, you can update a message with different lease values at runtime, and update different values across messages in the same queue.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus lock timeouts are defined in the queue metadata; however, you can renew the lock by calling the [RenewLock](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.renewlock.aspx) method.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus lock timeouts are defined in the queue metadata; however, you can renew the lock by calling the [RenewLock](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.renewlock.aspx) method.

trans-unit.source: The maximum timeout for a blocking receive operation in Service Bus queues is 24 days.
trans-unit.target: The maximum timeout for a blocking receive operation in Service Bus queues is 24 days.

trans-unit.source: However, REST-based timeouts have a maximum value of 55 seconds.
trans-unit.target: However, REST-based timeouts have a maximum value of 55 seconds.

trans-unit.source: Client-side batching provided by Service Bus enables a queue client to batch multiple messages into a single send operation.
trans-unit.target: Client-side batching provided by Service Bus enables a queue client to batch multiple messages into a single send operation.

trans-unit.source: Batching is only available for asynchronous send operations.
trans-unit.target: Batching is only available for asynchronous send operations.

trans-unit.source: Features such as the 200TB ceiling of Azure Queues (more when you virtualize accounts) and unlimited queues make it an ideal platform for SaaS providers.
trans-unit.target: Features such as the 200TB ceiling of Azure Queues (more when you virtualize accounts) and unlimited queues make it an ideal platform for SaaS providers.

trans-unit.source: Azure Queues provide a flexible and performant delegated access control mechanism.
trans-unit.target: Azure Queues provide a flexible and performant delegated access control mechanism.

trans-unit.source: This section compares advanced capabilities provided by Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: This section compares advanced capabilities provided by Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: **Minute Metrics**: provides real-time metrics for availability, TPS, API call counts, error counts, and more, all in real time (aggregated per minute and reported within a few minutes from what just happened in production.
trans-unit.target: **Minute Metrics**: provides real-time metrics for availability, TPS, API call counts, error counts, and more, all in real time (aggregated per minute and reported within a few minutes from what just happened in production.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [About Storage Analytics Metrics](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh343258.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [About Storage Analytics Metrics](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh343258.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Both queuing technologies enable a message to be scheduled for delivery at a later time.
trans-unit.target: Both queuing technologies enable a message to be scheduled for delivery at a later time.

trans-unit.source: Queue auto-forwarding enables thousands of queues to auto-forward their messages to a single queue, from which the receiving application consumes the message.
trans-unit.target: Queue auto-forwarding enables thousands of queues to auto-forward their messages to a single queue, from which the receiving application consumes the message.

trans-unit.source: You can use this mechanism to achieve security, control flow, and isolate storage between each message publisher.
trans-unit.target: You can use this mechanism to achieve security, control flow, and isolate storage between each message publisher.

trans-unit.source: Azure Queues provide support for updating message content.
trans-unit.target: Azure Queues provide support for updating message content.

trans-unit.source: You can use this functionality for persisting state information and incremental progress updates into the message so that it can be processed from the last known checkpoint, instead of starting from scratch.
trans-unit.target: You can use this functionality for persisting state information and incremental progress updates into the message so that it can be processed from the last known checkpoint, instead of starting from scratch.

trans-unit.source: With Service Bus queues, you can enable the same scenario through the use of message sessions.
trans-unit.target: With Service Bus queues, you can enable the same scenario through the use of message sessions.

trans-unit.source: Sessions enable you to save and retrieve the application processing state (by using [SetState](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.messagesession.setstate.aspx) and [GetState](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.messagesession.getstate.aspx)).
trans-unit.target: Sessions enable you to save and retrieve the application processing state (by using [SetState](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.messagesession.setstate.aspx) and [GetState](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.messagesession.getstate.aspx)).

trans-unit.source: Dead lettering, which is only supported by Service Bus queues, can be useful for isolating messages that cannot be processed successfully by the receiving application or when messages cannot reach their destination due to an expired time-to-live (TTL) property.
trans-unit.target: Dead lettering, which is only supported by Service Bus queues, can be useful for isolating messages that cannot be processed successfully by the receiving application or when messages cannot reach their destination due to an expired time-to-live (TTL) property.

trans-unit.source: The TTL value specifies how long a message remains in the queue.
trans-unit.target: The TTL value specifies how long a message remains in the queue.

trans-unit.source: With Service Bus, the message will be moved to a special queue called $DeadLetterQueue when the TTL period expires.
trans-unit.target: With Service Bus, the message will be moved to a special queue called $DeadLetterQueue when the TTL period expires.

trans-unit.source: To find “poison” messages in Azure Queues, when dequeuing a message the application examines the DequeueCount property of the message.
trans-unit.target: To find “poison” messages in Azure Queues, when dequeuing a message the application examines the DequeueCount property of the message.

trans-unit.source: If DequeueCount is above a given threshold, the application moves the message to an application-defined “dead letter” queue.
trans-unit.target: If DequeueCount is above a given threshold, the application moves the message to an application-defined “dead letter” queue.

trans-unit.source: Azure Queues enable you to obtain a detailed log of all of the transactions executed against the queue, as well as aggregated metrics.
trans-unit.target: Azure Queues enable you to obtain a detailed log of all of the transactions executed against the queue, as well as aggregated metrics.

trans-unit.source: Both of these options are useful for debugging and understanding how your application uses Azure Queues.
trans-unit.target: Both of these options are useful for debugging and understanding how your application uses Azure Queues.

trans-unit.source: They are also useful for performance-tuning your application and reducing the costs of using queues.
trans-unit.target: They are also useful for performance-tuning your application and reducing the costs of using queues.

trans-unit.source: The concept of “message sessions” supported by Service Bus allows messages that belong to a certain logical group to be associated with a given receiver, which in turn creates a session-like affinity between messages and their respective receivers.
trans-unit.target: The concept of “message sessions” supported by Service Bus allows messages that belong to a certain logical group to be associated with a given receiver, which in turn creates a session-like affinity between messages and their respective receivers.

trans-unit.source: You can enable this advanced functionality in Service Bus by setting the [SessionID](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.sessionid.aspx) property on a message.
trans-unit.target: You can enable this advanced functionality in Service Bus by setting the [SessionID](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.sessionid.aspx) property on a message.

trans-unit.source: Receivers can then listen on a specific session ID and receive messages that share the specified session identifier.
trans-unit.target: Receivers can then listen on a specific session ID and receive messages that share the specified session identifier.

trans-unit.source: The duplication detection functionality supported by Service Bus queues automatically removes duplicate messages sent to a queue or topic, based on the value of the [MessageID](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.messageid.aspx) property.
trans-unit.target: The duplication detection functionality supported by Service Bus queues automatically removes duplicate messages sent to a queue or topic, based on the value of the [MessageID](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.brokeredmessage.messageid.aspx) property.

trans-unit.source: This section compares Azure Queues and Service Bus queues from the perspective of capacity and quotas that may apply.
trans-unit.target: This section compares Azure Queues and Service Bus queues from the perspective of capacity and quotas that may apply.

trans-unit.source: (limited to a single storage account capacity)
trans-unit.target: (limited to a single storage account capacity)

trans-unit.source: (defined upon creation of a queue and [enabling partitioning](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn520246.aspx) – see the “Additional Information” section)
trans-unit.target: (defined upon creation of a queue and [enabling partitioning](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn520246.aspx) – see the “Additional Information” section)

trans-unit.source: Azure supports large messages by combining queues and blobs – at which point you can enqueue up to 200GB for a single item.
trans-unit.target: Azure supports large messages by combining queues and blobs – at which point you can enqueue up to 200GB for a single item.

trans-unit.source: (including both header and body, maximum header size: 64 KB)
trans-unit.target: (including both header and body, maximum header size: 64 KB)

trans-unit.source: (100 concurrent connection limit only applies to TCP protocol-based communication)
trans-unit.target: (100 concurrent connection limit only applies to TCP protocol-based communication)

trans-unit.source: Service Bus enforces queue size limits.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus enforces queue size limits.

trans-unit.source: The maximum queue size is specified upon creation of the queue and can have a value between 1 and 80 GB.
trans-unit.target: The maximum queue size is specified upon creation of the queue and can have a value between 1 and 80 GB.

trans-unit.source: If the queue size value set on creation of the queue is reached, additional incoming messages will be rejected and an exception will be received by the calling code.
trans-unit.target: If the queue size value set on creation of the queue is reached, additional incoming messages will be rejected and an exception will be received by the calling code.

trans-unit.source: For more information about quotas in Service Bus, see [Service Bus Quotas](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ee732538.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about quotas in Service Bus, see [Service Bus Quotas](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ee732538.aspx).

trans-unit.source: You can create Service Bus queues in 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 GB sizes (the default is 1 GB).
trans-unit.target: You can create Service Bus queues in 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 GB sizes (the default is 1 GB).

trans-unit.source: With partitioning enabled (which is the default), Service Bus creates 16 partitions for each GB you specify.
trans-unit.target: With partitioning enabled (which is the default), Service Bus creates 16 partitions for each GB you specify.

trans-unit.source: As such, if you create a queue that’s 5 GB in size, with 16 partitions the maximum queue size becomes (5 * 16) = 80 GB.
trans-unit.target: As such, if you create a queue that’s 5 GB in size, with 16 partitions the maximum queue size becomes (5 * 16) = 80 GB.

trans-unit.source: You can see the maximum size of your partitioned queue or topic by looking at its entry on the Azure management portal.
trans-unit.target: You can see the maximum size of your partitioned queue or topic by looking at its entry on the Azure management portal.

trans-unit.source: With Azure Queues, if the content of the message is not XML-safe, then it must be **Base64** encoded.
trans-unit.target: With Azure Queues, if the content of the message is not XML-safe, then it must be **Base64** encoded.

trans-unit.source: If you **Base64**-encode the message, the user payload can be up to 48 KB, instead of 64 KB.
trans-unit.target: If you **Base64**-encode the message, the user payload can be up to 48 KB, instead of 64 KB.

trans-unit.source: With Service Bus queues, each message stored in a queue is comprised of two parts: a header and a body.
trans-unit.target: With Service Bus queues, each message stored in a queue is comprised of two parts: a header and a body.

trans-unit.source: The total size of the message cannot exceed 256 KB.
trans-unit.target: The total size of the message cannot exceed 256 KB.

trans-unit.source: When clients communicate with Service Bus queues over the TCP protocol, the maximum number of concurrent connections to a single Service Bus queue is limited to 100.
trans-unit.target: When clients communicate with Service Bus queues over the TCP protocol, the maximum number of concurrent connections to a single Service Bus queue is limited to 100.

trans-unit.source: This number is shared between senders and receivers.
trans-unit.target: This number is shared between senders and receivers.

trans-unit.source: If this quota is reached, subsequent requests for additional connections will be rejected and an exception will be received by the calling code.
trans-unit.target: If this quota is reached, subsequent requests for additional connections will be rejected and an exception will be received by the calling code.

trans-unit.source: This limit is not imposed on clients connecting to the queues using REST-based API.
trans-unit.target: This limit is not imposed on clients connecting to the queues using REST-based API.

trans-unit.source: If you require more than 10,000 queues in a single Service Bus namespace, you can contact the Azure support team and request an increase.
trans-unit.target: If you require more than 10,000 queues in a single Service Bus namespace, you can contact the Azure support team and request an increase.

trans-unit.source: To scale beyond 10,000 queues with Service Bus, you can also create additional namespaces using the Azure management portal.
trans-unit.target: To scale beyond 10,000 queues with Service Bus, you can also create additional namespaces using the Azure management portal.

trans-unit.source: This section compares the management features provided by Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: This section compares the management features provided by Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: (letters in a queue name must be lowercase)
trans-unit.target: (letters in a queue name must be lowercase)

trans-unit.source: (approximate value if messages expire beyond the TTL without being deleted)
trans-unit.target: (approximate value if messages expire beyond the TTL without being deleted)

trans-unit.source: Azure Queues provide support for arbitrary attributes that can be applied to the queue description, in the form of name/value pairs.
trans-unit.target: Azure Queues provide support for arbitrary attributes that can be applied to the queue description, in the form of name/value pairs.

trans-unit.source: Both queue technologies offer the ability to peek a message without having to lock it, which can be useful when implementing a queue explorer/browser tool.
trans-unit.target: Both queue technologies offer the ability to peek a message without having to lock it, which can be useful when implementing a queue explorer/browser tool.

trans-unit.source: The Service Bus .NET brokered messaging APIs leverage full-duplex TCP connections for improved performance when compared to REST over HTTP, and they support the AMQP 1.0 standard protocol.
trans-unit.target: The Service Bus .NET brokered messaging APIs leverage full-duplex TCP connections for improved performance when compared to REST over HTTP, and they support the AMQP 1.0 standard protocol.

trans-unit.source: Azure queue names can be 3-63 characters long, can contain lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens.
trans-unit.target: Azure queue names can be 3-63 characters long, can contain lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Naming Queues and Metadata](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dd179349.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Naming Queues and Metadata](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dd179349.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queue names can be up to 260 characters long and have less restrictive naming rules.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queue names can be up to 260 characters long and have less restrictive naming rules.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queue names can contain letters, numbers, periods (.), hyphens (-), and underscores (_).
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queue names can contain letters, numbers, periods (.), hyphens (-), and underscores (_).

trans-unit.source: This section compares Azure Queues and Service Bus queues from a performance perspective.
trans-unit.target: This section compares Azure Queues and Service Bus queues from a performance perspective.

trans-unit.source: (throttled requests are not treated as billable)
trans-unit.target: (throttled requests are not treated as billable)

trans-unit.source: (throttled requests are not treated as billable)
trans-unit.target: (throttled requests are not treated as billable)

trans-unit.source: A single Azure queue can process up to 2,000 transactions per second.
trans-unit.target: A single Azure queue can process up to 2,000 transactions per second.

trans-unit.source: A transaction is either a **Put**, **Get**, or **Delete** operation.
trans-unit.target: A transaction is either a **Put**, **Get**, or **Delete** operation.

trans-unit.source: Sending a single message to a queue (**Put**) is counted as one transaction, but receiving a message is often a two-step process involving the retrieval (**Get**), followed by a request to remove the message from the queue (**Delete**).
trans-unit.target: Sending a single message to a queue (**Put**) is counted as one transaction, but receiving a message is often a two-step process involving the retrieval (**Get**), followed by a request to remove the message from the queue (**Delete**).

trans-unit.source: As a result, a successful dequeue operation usually involves two transactions.
trans-unit.target: As a result, a successful dequeue operation usually involves two transactions.

trans-unit.source: Retrieving multiple messages in a batch can reduce the impact of this, as you can **Get** up to 32 messages in a single transaction, followed by a **Delete** for each of them.
trans-unit.target: Retrieving multiple messages in a batch can reduce the impact of this, as you can **Get** up to 32 messages in a single transaction, followed by a **Delete** for each of them.

trans-unit.source: For better throughput, you can create multiple queues (a storage account can have an unlimited number of queues).
trans-unit.target: For better throughput, you can create multiple queues (a storage account can have an unlimited number of queues).

trans-unit.source: When your application reaches the maximum throughput for an Azure queue, an “HTTP 503 Server Busy” response is usually returned from the queue service.
trans-unit.target: When your application reaches the maximum throughput for an Azure queue, an “HTTP 503 Server Busy” response is usually returned from the queue service.

trans-unit.source: When this occurs, the application should trigger the retry logic with exponential back-off delay.
trans-unit.target: When this occurs, the application should trigger the retry logic with exponential back-off delay.

trans-unit.source: The latency of Azure Queues is 10 milliseconds on average when handling small messages (less than 10 KB) from a hosted service located in the same location (region) as the storage account.
trans-unit.target: The latency of Azure Queues is 10 milliseconds on average when handling small messages (less than 10 KB) from a hosted service located in the same location (region) as the storage account.

trans-unit.source: Both Azure Queues and Service Bus queues enforce throttling behavior by rejecting requests to a queue that is being throttled.
trans-unit.target: Both Azure Queues and Service Bus queues enforce throttling behavior by rejecting requests to a queue that is being throttled.

trans-unit.source: However, neither of them treats throttled requests as billable.
trans-unit.target: However, neither of them treats throttled requests as billable.

trans-unit.source: Benchmarks against Service Bus queues have demonstrated that a single queue can achieve a message throughput of up to 2,000 messages per second with a message size of approximately 1 KB.
trans-unit.target: Benchmarks against Service Bus queues have demonstrated that a single queue can achieve a message throughput of up to 2,000 messages per second with a message size of approximately 1 KB.

trans-unit.source: To achieve higher throughput, use multiple queues.
trans-unit.target: To achieve higher throughput, use multiple queues.

trans-unit.source: For more information about performance optimization with Service Bus, see [Best Practices for Performance Improvements Using Service Bus Brokered Messaging](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh528527.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about performance optimization with Service Bus, see [Best Practices for Performance Improvements Using Service Bus Brokered Messaging](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh528527.aspx).

trans-unit.source: When the maximum throughput is reached for a Service Bus queue, a [ServerBusyException](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.serverbusyexception.aspx) (when using the.NET brokered messaging API) or HTTP 503 (when using the REST-based API) response is returned to the queue client, indicating that the queue is being throttled.
trans-unit.target: When the maximum throughput is reached for a Service Bus queue, a [ServerBusyException](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.serverbusyexception.aspx) (when using the.NET brokered messaging API) or HTTP 503 (when using the REST-based API) response is returned to the queue client, indicating that the queue is being throttled.

trans-unit.source: This section discusses the authentication and authorization features supported by Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: This section discusses the authentication and authorization features supported by Azure Queues and Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: Every request to either of the queuing technologies must be authenticated.
trans-unit.target: Every request to either of the queuing technologies must be authenticated.

trans-unit.source: Public queues with anonymous access are not supported.
trans-unit.target: Public queues with anonymous access are not supported.

trans-unit.source: Using SAS, you can address this scenario by publishing a write-only SAS, read-only SAS, or even a full-access SAS.
trans-unit.target: Using SAS, you can address this scenario by publishing a write-only SAS, read-only SAS, or even a full-access SAS.

trans-unit.source: The authentication scheme provided by Azure Queues involves the use of a symmetric key, which is a hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC), computed with the SHA-256 algorithm and encoded as a **Base64** string.
trans-unit.target: The authentication scheme provided by Azure Queues involves the use of a symmetric key, which is a hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC), computed with the SHA-256 algorithm and encoded as a **Base64** string.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the respective protocol, see [Authenticating Access to Your Storage Account](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh225339.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about the respective protocol, see [Authenticating Access to Your Storage Account](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh225339.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues support a similar model using symmetric keys.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues support a similar model using symmetric keys.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Shared Access Signature Authentication with Service Bus](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn170477.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Shared Access Signature Authentication with Service Bus](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn170477.aspx).

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Azure Active Directory Access Control (also known as Access Control Service or ACS) supported by Service Bus offers three distinct roles: **Admin**, **Sender**, and **Receiver**, which is not supported at this time for Azure Queues.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Azure Active Directory Access Control (also known as Access Control Service or ACS) supported by Service Bus offers three distinct roles: **Admin**, **Sender**, and **Receiver**, which is not supported at this time for Azure Queues.

trans-unit.source: Because Service Bus offers ACS integration, it enables you to federate with Active Directory (through the use of ADFS) and other common web identity providers.
trans-unit.target: Because Service Bus offers ACS integration, it enables you to federate with Active Directory (through the use of ADFS) and other common web identity providers.

trans-unit.source: This section compares Azure Queues and Service Bus queues from a cost perspective.
trans-unit.target: This section compares Azure Queues and Service Bus queues from a cost perspective.

trans-unit.source: (querying an empty queue is counted as a billable transaction)
trans-unit.target: (querying an empty queue is counted as a billable transaction)

trans-unit.source: (a receive against an empty queue is considered a billable message)
trans-unit.target: (a receive against an empty queue is considered a billable message)

trans-unit.source: Data transfers are charged based on the total amount of data leaving the Azure datacenters via the internet in a given billing period.
trans-unit.target: Data transfers are charged based on the total amount of data leaving the Azure datacenters via the internet in a given billing period.

trans-unit.source: Data transfers between Azure services located within the same region are not subject to charge.
trans-unit.target: Data transfers between Azure services located within the same region are not subject to charge.

trans-unit.source: As of this writing, all inbound data transfers are not subject to charge.
trans-unit.target: As of this writing, all inbound data transfers are not subject to charge.

trans-unit.source: Given the support for long polling, using Service Bus queues can be cost effective in situations where low-latency delivery is required.
trans-unit.target: Given the support for long polling, using Service Bus queues can be cost effective in situations where low-latency delivery is required.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] All costs are subject to change.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] All costs are subject to change.

trans-unit.source: This table reflects current pricing as of the writing of this article and does not include any promotional offers that may currently be available.
trans-unit.target: This table reflects current pricing as of the writing of this article and does not include any promotional offers that may currently be available.

trans-unit.source: For up-to-date information about Azure pricing, see the [Azure pricing](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/) page.
trans-unit.target: For up-to-date information about Azure pricing, see the [Azure pricing](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/) page.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Service Bus pricing, see [Service Bus pricing]((http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/service-bus/).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Service Bus pricing, see [Service Bus pricing]((http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/service-bus/).

trans-unit.source: By gaining a deeper understanding of the two technologies, you will be able to make a more informed decision on which queue technology to use, and when.
trans-unit.target: By gaining a deeper understanding of the two technologies, you will be able to make a more informed decision on which queue technology to use, and when.

trans-unit.source: The decision on when to use Azure Queues or Service Bus queues clearly depends on a number of factors.
trans-unit.target: The decision on when to use Azure Queues or Service Bus queues clearly depends on a number of factors.

trans-unit.source: These factors may depend heavily on the individual needs of your application and its architecture.
trans-unit.target: These factors may depend heavily on the individual needs of your application and its architecture.

trans-unit.source: If your application already uses the core capabilities of Microsoft Azure, you may prefer to choose Azure Queues, especially if you require basic communication and messaging between services or need queues that can be larger than 80 GB in size.
trans-unit.target: If your application already uses the core capabilities of Microsoft Azure, you may prefer to choose Azure Queues, especially if you require basic communication and messaging between services or need queues that can be larger than 80 GB in size.

trans-unit.source: Because Service Bus queues provide a number of advanced features, such as sessions, transactions, duplicate detection, automatic dead-lettering, and durable publish/subscribe capabilities, they may be a preferred choice if you are building a hybrid application or if your application otherwise requires these features.
trans-unit.target: Because Service Bus queues provide a number of advanced features, such as sessions, transactions, duplicate detection, automatic dead-lettering, and durable publish/subscribe capabilities, they may be a preferred choice if you are building a hybrid application or if your application otherwise requires these features.

trans-unit.source: The following articles provide more guidance and information about using Azure Queues or Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: The following articles provide more guidance and information about using Azure Queues or Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.target: How to Use Service Bus Queues

trans-unit.target: How to Use the Queue Storage Service

trans-unit.target: Best Practices for Performance Improvements Using Service Bus Brokered Messaging

trans-unit.target: Introducing Queues and Topics in Azure Service Bus

trans-unit.target: The Developer's Guide to Service Bus

trans-unit.target: Using the Queuing Service in Azure
